item.title: In Zimbabwe’s Succession Battle, Mugabe Pulls the Strings
item.description: President Robert Mugabe is presiding over — and possibly choreographing — an increasingly fierce internal scramble for the rewards of high office.
item.dc:creator: By ALAN COWELL
item.media:description: President Robert G. Mugabe of Zimbabwe and his wife, Grace, in Harare, the capital, in October. Mr. Mugabe, 90, is Africa’s oldest leader.

item.title: World Briefing: Britain: 12 Are Injured in Blast at Hotel
item.description: More than a dozen were hurt in what the police said they suspected was a natural-gas explosion in the basement of a central London hotel just before midnight Friday.
item.dc:creator: By STEVEN ERLANGER

item.title: In a Shift, Obama Extends U.S. Role in Afghan Combat
item.description: The president’s order would allow American forces to carry out missions against the Taliban and other militant groups threatening American troops or the Afghan government, sources said.
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.dc:creator: By MARK MAZZETTI and ERIC SCHMITT

item.title: Suddenly, Sri Lanka Presidential Elections Become a Real Contest
item.description: In a surprise, the president’s health minister, who also was the general secretary of the ruling party, quit to run as the opposition candidate.
item.dc:creator: By DHARISHA BASTIANS and GARDINER HARRIS

item.title: As Immigration Rules Shift, Migrants’ Joy Is Tempered
item.description: Some expressed confusion about how they would obtain the new documents that would allow them to obtain work permits under the president’s plan. And immigrants who came here legally expressed betrayal.
item.dc:creator: By JULIA PRESTON
item.media:description: Oscar Alfaro hugs his aunt, Carmen Paz, at a Maryland event for the president’s address.

item.title: World Briefing: Madagascar: Plague Outbreak Kills 40
item.description: The World Health Organization reported that an outbreak of plague, the infamous scourge that killed millions in the Dark Ages, has been recorded in parts of Madagascar.
item.dc:creator: By RICK GLADSTONE

item.title: Brinkmanship Heightens as Deadline for a Nuclear Deal With Iran Looms
item.description: Difficulties in the talks suggested it was unlikely that any agreement that might be announced on Monday would be a complete one, and that a deadline extension would be needed.
item.dc:creator: By MICHAEL R. GORDON and DAVID E. SANGER
item.media:description: Secretary of State John Kerry left a meeting in Vienna on Friday where negotiations on a nuclear deal with Iran are being held.

item.title: In Change of Strategy, China Cuts Interest Rate
item.description: The step suggests that policy makers have become nervous about the pace at which growth is slowing, though analysts said the change’s effect would be small.
item.dc:creator: By NEIL GOUGH
item.media:description: A job fair in Shanghai on Thursday. China's interest rate cut reflects concern that the economy is growing too slowly.

item.title: Officials Revise Goals on Containing Ebola After Signs of Wider Exposure in Mali
item.description: The leaders of the United Nations and the World Health Organization said nearly 500 people in Mali and Guinea had been exposed to a sickened imam who had been misdiagnosed.
item.dc:creator: By RICK GLADSTONE and SOMINI SENGUPTA

item.title: Dispatch: Tiptoeing Through Kurdistan
item.description: The hospitality is overwhelming, but so are the grievances and the conflicts.
item.dc:creator: By PAUL SALOPEK
item.media:description: Kurds at the funerals in Turkey of three Kurdish fighters who died last month in clashes in Syria with the Islamic State.

item.title: House Intel Panel Debunks Many Benghazi Theories
item.description: A two-year investigation by the Republican-controlled House Intelligence Committee found that the C.I.A. and military acted properly in responding to the attack on a U.S. diplomatic compound in Benghazi.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: ISIS Taunts United States and Britain in New Video
item.description: In a video released Friday, John Cantlie, a British journalist being held by the Islamic State, called on the United States and Britain to negotiate prisoner swaps or pay ransoms.
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: By BEN HUBBARD

item.title: Biden Assails Russian Intervention in Ukraine as ‘Unacceptable’
item.description: Marking a year since the start of protests that ousted the last government, the American vice president also called on Kiev to complete a range of reforms.
item.dc:creator: By ANDREW ROTH

item.title: After Rocky Transition, Tunisia Is Set for First Democratic Presidential Vote
item.description: The front-runner, Beji Caid Essebsi, promises stability to a country that has had a few rocky years since kicking off the Arab Spring.
item.dc:creator: By CARLOTTA GALL
item.media:description: The Tunisian presidential candidate Beji Caid Essebsi, leader of the secular Nidaa Tounes party, at a campaign event in Beja this week.

item.title: Jordan Arrests Muslim Brotherhood Official Over Criticism of United Arab Emirates
item.description: The deputy head of the Muslim Brotherhood, Zaki Bani Rushaid, was detained over an article he wrote accused the United Arab Emirates of sponsoring terrorism.
item.dc:creator: By RANA F. SWEIS

item.title: Yangon’s Hero, Wielding Power of Stop and Go
item.description: As liberalization swamps Myanmar’s largest city with cars, a young police sergeant adept at managing the flow has been winning praise — and quite a few tips.
item.dc:creator: By THOMAS FULLER
item.media:credit: Tomas Munita for The New York Times
item.media:description: Sgt. Khin Myint Maung directing traffic at a busy intersection in Yangon, Myanmar. His accolades are as much an indictment of others’ corruption as they are a tribute to him.

item.title: In Newly Gridlocked Yangon, a Hero Emerges: a Traffic Cop
item.description: As liberalization swamps Myanmar’s largest city with cars, a young police sergeant adept at managing the flow has been winning praise — and quite a few tips.
item.dc:creator: By THOMAS FULLER
item.media:credit: Tomas Munita for The New York Times
item.media:description: Sgt. Khin Myint Maung directing traffic at a busy intersection in Yangon, Myanmar. His accolades are as much an indictment of others' corruption as they are a tribute to him.

item.title: Q. and A.: The Diplomatic Effort, and What a Final Agreement Might Look Like
item.description: The United States, its allies, and other nations possessing nuclear weapons are striving to reach a deal with Iran to limit its nuclear power to peaceful uses.
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.dc:creator: By DAVID E. SANGER
item.media:description: President Jimmy Carter and the shah of Iran, Mohammed Reza Pahlavi, at a state dinner in Iran in 1977. The United States provided Iran with its first nuclear reactor.

item.title: Allure of ISIS for Pakistanis Is on the Rise
item.description: The Islamic State is not operating in Pakistan, officials say, but militants are beginning to invoke its name and some are pledging their allegiance.
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: By DECLAN WALSH
item.media:description: An empty police checkpoint near Karachi, Pakistan, painted with Islamic State graffiti.

item.title: The Saturday Profile: Extolling Moderation to Get Cubans Talking About Politics
item.description: Two former journalists have created a space in Havana where dissidents, communists, artists, exiles and intellectuals alike can discuss national issues.
item.dc:creator: By VICTORIA BURNETT
item.media:credit: Jose Goitia for The New York Times
item.media:description: Roberto Veiga González, left, and Lenier González Mederos, who started Cuba Posible, a project in Havana that aims to test the government’s threshold for debate.

item.title: Police Question Indian Guru and Find Arsenal in His Compound
item.description: The police said homemade bombs and firearms were found inside his vast compound, which included a hall the size of two football fields where he would deliver sermons.
item.dc:creator: By ELLEN BARRY
item.media:description: Baba Rampal Maharaj, 63, who claims to be the reincarnation of a 15th-century mystic poet, was brought to court in Chandigarh, in northern India, on Thursday.

item.title: After Outcry, Britain Bars ‘Pickup Artist’ From Entering
item.description: The British government refused to grant a visa to Julien Blanc, a 25-year-old American, after a public outcry over his abusive techniques.
item.dc:creator: By KATRIN BENNHOLD
item.media:description: In a video available on YouTube, Julien Blanc told an audience of men in Tokyo: “If you’re a white male, you can do what you want.”

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: Q. and A.: Kevin Niu on Movies and the Hunger for Horror in China
item.description: Despite being about to receive his Ph.D. in physics from Harvard, Kevin Niu plans to eschew the academic life to follow his calling in the entertainment industry.
item.dc:creator: By MICHAEL FORSYTHE
item.media:description: Kevin Niu, Ph.D. student in physics and producer of the horror movie "Abattoir."

item.title: Power Struggle in Zambia Intensifies With Suspension of Acting President
item.description: Members of the governing Patriotic Front said Guy Scott had been suspended from his party post but would remain the interim leader of the country, news reports said.
item.dc:creator: By ALAN COWELL

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: China’s Millenniums-Old Salt Monopoly No Match for Economic Reform
item.description: The country plans to scrap its state monopoly on the sale of salt, a move that would mark the end of a system that can be traced back to 685 B.C.
item.dc:creator: By AUSTIN RAMZY
item.media:description: Employees gather salt at a saltern in Rizhao, a coastal city in Shandong Province.
